This privacy policy describes the privacy considerations made by MUSES for those whose mobile devices are monitored (further referred to individuals/you). With this policy we want to make sure you understand how MUSES works, and how we use your personal information gathered through our software and by our services. We want you to feel secure that your privacy interests are being respected within the bounds of this policy. This privacy policy applies to all our software and services. \n\nAll your personal information being collected is treated according to the procedures below. \n\nFor all legal issues, Belgian law is applicable. What information do we collect? \nThe use of the information being collected by our services shall be limited to the purpose of providing the service for which our customer (your employer/contracting company) has engaged MUSES. This means that the collection of your personal information will not exceed that what is necessary to assess the security risks brought forward by the company/our customer. In order to fully assess the security risks posed by the use of your mobile device, MUSES will monitor certain aspects of your device-behavior.
The gathered information may include device identified and device username.
The information collected and tracked by MUSES depends on the system configurations chosen by your employer/our customer. The MUSES system is designed to meet the requirements resulting from the security policies of the company (customer of MUSES).
What do we use your information for?
The information we retrieve from your mobile device is used only to assess the security risks, by the MUSES system.
How can you correct and update your information?
You are in control of your personal information. You can request access to the personal information we collect about you, and you can always request corrections or ask us to update the information about you.
We will respond to those requests within 30 days.
Do we disclose any information to third parties?
MUSES will not divulge any of your personal information to any other organization.
How do we protect your information?
Your personal information will not be kept longer than necessary to provide the MUSES service and as required by the law. During the time your personal information is processed by MUSES, it is kept safely.
Your account information is kept confidential and secure via a unique username and password that is selected by you. We encrypt the transmission of sensitive information (such as login credentials).
Your username and password should be kept confidential because they are the key to accessing the information held by MUSES about you. If your computer or mobile device is accessible to or by others, you should log out the MUSES services whenever you leave the device. If you have any questions about this you can contact us at:
info@muses.com
Your consent
Before you can proceed you must confirm that you read this Privacy Policy.
Before you can proceed you must confirm that you understand and agrees with this Privacy Policy.
Changes to the policy
This policy was last modified on 13 April 2014.
In case this Privacy Policy will change in the future, you will be notified of these changes by a notification on your MUSES login page.
Contacting us for more information
If you have any questions regarding this Privacy Policy, you can contact us by e-mail at:
info@muses.com

<p class=MsoNormal><b><span style='font-size:14.0pt;mso-fareast-font-family: "Times New Roman";mso-fareast-theme-font:major-fareast;mso-bidi-font-family: "Times New Roman";mso-bidi-theme-font:major-bidi;color:#365F91;mso-themecolor: accent1;mso-themeshade:191;mso-ansi-language:EN-US'><o:p> </o:p></span></b></p>
<h1><a name="_Toc421128969"><span style='font-family:"Calibri",sans-serif; mso-ascii-theme-font:minor-latin;mso-hansi-theme-font:minor-latin;mso-ansi-language: EN-US'>Password strength</span></a><span style='font-family:"Calibri",sans-serif; mso-ascii-theme-font:minor-latin;mso-hansi-theme-font:minor-latin;mso-ansi-language: EN-US'><o:p></o:p></span></h1>
<p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>A password is strongest when it has a sufficient number of (apparently) meaningless characters ideally 8 or more. To make it still memorable it is recommended to turn a phrase that is meaningful to you, such is My birthday is on Sept 9, 1978, into an acronym, such as <span class=SpellE>mBd@y</span>=9.9/78. Alternatively you can create a sentence combined with numbers and special characters such as MY_fav0rit3_drag0n_N3EVER_gr0ws_0ld which can be easier to memorize and safer due to its length. Never use the same password for multiple areas, change your passwords regularly, and always log out of any accounts if you leave a website. To lighten the cognitive load you can also use a password manager program in which case you only have to remember the master password. If a password is cracked, personal data can be stolen and identity theft can occur, using your data to commit fraud or other crimes and your account can be used to spam or scam your contacts.<o:p></o:p></span></p>
<p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'><o:p> </o:p></span></p>
<h1><a name="_Toc421128970"><span style='font-family:"Calibri",sans-serif; mso-ascii-theme-font:minor-latin;mso-hansi-theme-font:minor-latin;mso-ansi-language: EN-US'>Information security at the workplace: Strangers</span></a><span style='font-family:"Calibri",sans-serif;mso-ascii-theme-font:minor-latin; mso-hansi-theme-font:minor-latin;mso-ansi-language:EN-US'><o:p></o:p></span></h1>
<p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>Nobody should ever follow you (or cross you) through a doorway that can normally only be crossed with an access card or a key without anything that identifies them as authorized and then be left to their own devices. Strangers should not walk around in your office space unaccompanied but it is also not necessary to treat everyone as a potential criminal. If you see someone you do not know stay polite, gain an understanding of who they are and whom they are here to see and make sure they get to your colleague or to security personal who can accompany them personally. <o:p></o:p></span></p>
<p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>It is still important to be alert, so do not leave your office without securing your laptop and any sensitive documents in some way and keep your workspace neat to make sure you notice if something is missing.<o:p></o:p></span></p>
<p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'><o:p> </o:p></span></p>
<h1><a name="_Toc421128971"><span style='font-family:"Calibri",sans-serif; mso-ascii-theme-font:minor-latin;mso-hansi-theme-font:minor-latin;mso-ansi-language: EN-US'>Laptop security in public</span></a><span style='font-family:"Calibri",sans-serif; mso-ascii-theme-font:minor-latin;mso-hansi-theme-font:minor-latin;mso-ansi-language: EN-US'><o:p></o:p></span></h1>
<p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>It is always safest to keep your laptop with you. Otherwise someone could get access to company files or address books, install malware, or simply steal your laptop. Never leave it in a public place.<o:p></o:p></span></p>
<p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'><o:p> </o:p></span></p>
<h1><a name="_Toc421128972"><span style='font-family:"Calibri",sans-serif; mso-ascii-theme-font:minor-latin;mso-hansi-theme-font:minor-latin;mso-ansi-language: EN-US'>Secure storage of data</span></a><span style='font-family:"Calibri",sans-serif; mso-ascii-theme-font:minor-latin;mso-hansi-theme-font:minor-latin;mso-ansi-language: EN-US'><o:p></o:p></span></h1>
<p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>Your work data should only be stored on your personal network drive which is backed up regularly. This is, however, the only way to safely store and back up your data. Other theoretical back-up options such as USB drives, cloud services, or your personal computer are not safe and create vulnerabilities in terms of improper access. If you only store your data on your hard drive (instead of your personal network within your companys network) it cannot be restored if it is lost somehow.<o:p></o:p></span></p>
<p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'><o:p> </o:p></span></p>
<h1><a name="_Toc421128973"><span style='font-family:"Calibri",sans-serif; mso-ascii-theme-font:minor-latin;mso-hansi-theme-font:minor-latin;mso-ansi-language: EN-US'>Secure handling of spam emails</span></a><span style='font-family:"Calibri",sans-serif; mso-ascii-theme-font:minor-latin;mso-hansi-theme-font:minor-latin;mso-ansi-language: EN-US'><o:p></o:p></span></h1>
<p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>If you receive an email that looks like spam it should be forwarded to your IT support and then either erased or moved to a separate folder and marked as spam to help your email client to identify spam in the future. Dont ever reply in any way as this just confirms your account as active and used. It is also never a good idea to click on links which you cannot be sure are trustworthy as you risk download of malware.<o:p></o:p></span></p>
<p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'><o:p> </o:p></span></p>
<h1><a name="_Toc421128974"><span style='font-family:"Calibri",sans-serif; mso-ascii-theme-font:minor-latin;mso-hansi-theme-font:minor-latin;mso-ansi-language: EN-US'>Secure handling of email attachments</span></a><span style='font-family: "Calibri",sans-serif;mso-ascii-theme-font:minor-latin;mso-hansi-theme-font: minor-latin;mso-ansi-language:EN-US'><o:p></o:p></span></h1>
<p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>Attached files should only be opened if it is clear what they contain and if the sender can be trusted. Ideally your security software scans every attachment automatically for malware (make sure the software is always up to date). If the sender is known and you receive an unexpected attachment it is advisable to inform the sender of this so that it can be clarified if there might be a safety issue that the sender should address. The same precautions apply with files transferred via instant messaging. You can also check if a file is really a file or an application via the <i style='mso-bidi-font-style:normal'>Get Info </i>command in the finder window.<o:p></o:p></span></p>
<p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'><o:p> </o:p></span></p>
<h1><a name="_Toc421128975"><span style='font-family:"Calibri",sans-serif; mso-ascii-theme-font:minor-latin;mso-hansi-theme-font:minor-latin;mso-ansi-language: EN-US'>Internet connection safety</span></a><span style='font-family:"Calibri",sans-serif; mso-ascii-theme-font:minor-latin;mso-hansi-theme-font:minor-latin;mso-ansi-language: EN-US'><o:p></o:p></span></h1>
<p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>You can safely use internet connections outside of your companys network as long as you ensure they are encrypted and you stay on secure websites with the prefix https. If you have the option you can make your access even safer by using a VPN (virtual private network) client to access the internet. The biggest threats when using an unsafe internet connection are someone tracking your online movements, potentially seeing passwords, emails, documents, and more.<o:p></o:p></span></p>
<p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'><o:p> </o:p></span></p>
<h1><a name="_Toc421128976"><span style='font-family:"Calibri",sans-serif; mso-ascii-theme-font:minor-latin;mso-hansi-theme-font:minor-latin;mso-ansi-language: EN-US'>Secure handling of sensitive information: Encryption</span></a><span style='font-family:"Calibri",sans-serif;mso-ascii-theme-font:minor-latin; mso-hansi-theme-font:minor-latin;mso-ansi-language:EN-US'><o:p></o:p></span></h1>
<p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>Obsessing over encrypting every single file you own on your hard drive and in your cloud storage is unnecessary and a hassle but encrypting sensitive files for storage or transfer is smart and advisable. If your hard drive is encrypted your information will be protected if your turned off laptop is stolen but if your laptop is running your information will be in a decrypted state.<o:p></o:p></span></p>
<p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'><o:p> </o:p></span></p>
<h1><a name="_Toc421128977"><span style='font-family:"Calibri",sans-serif; mso-ascii-theme-font:minor-latin;mso-hansi-theme-font:minor-latin;mso-ansi-language: EN-US'>Web browser security</span></a><span style='font-family:"Calibri",sans-serif; mso-ascii-theme-font:minor-latin;mso-hansi-theme-font:minor-latin;mso-ansi-language: EN-US'><o:p></o:p></span></h1>
<p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>No single browser is ever completely safe; it is therefore important to make it as safe as possible via all setting options available and make sure it is up to date. It is also advisable to sign up to alerts to stay informed on new security issues and be particularly cautious with plug-ins and extensions as these can compromise the protection of your browser.<o:p></o:p></span></p>
<p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>There are, however, specific security plug-ins that can boost the protection of your browser, such as <i style='mso-bidi-font-style:normal'>HTTPS Everywhere </i>or <i style='mso-bidi-font-style:normal'>WOT (Web of Trust)</i>. Beside all this it is still important to browse smart stay alert, think before you click and do not click on any links or download anything if you are not sure the source can be trusted. Anonymizing software can successfully hide your identity but is not enough on its own; it is also likely not going to be possible to follow the required protocol to keep you from being identified for all your everyday activities.<o:p></o:p></span></p>
<p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'><o:p> </o:p></span></p>
<h1><a name="_Toc421128978"><span style='font-family:"Calibri",sans-serif; mso-ascii-theme-font:minor-latin;mso-hansi-theme-font:minor-latin;mso-ansi-language: EN-US'>Smartphone security</span></a><span style='font-family:"Calibri",sans-serif; mso-ascii-theme-font:minor-latin;mso-hansi-theme-font:minor-latin;mso-ansi-language: EN-US'><o:p></o:p></span></h1>
<p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>A smartphone is essentially a connected PC that fits in your pocket, so most of the same safety rules apply with some additional ones due to the specific nature of the device. Use security software, be careful with what you download, do not reply to any suspicious emails or text message, make sure all software is always up to date, encrypt your data, back your data up regularly, and use a screen lock.<o:p></o:p></span></p>
<p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>Further, turn off <span class=SpellE>Wifi</span> and Bluetooth whenever you are not using it and specifically when you are speaking or entering sensitive information. Pay attention to permission / access requests when you install apps and do not jailbreak / root your phone as this will strip away security. Make sure you have a possibility to remotely disable your phone or wipe it clean should it get lost or stolen and react fast in such a case.<o:p></o:p></span></p>
</div>
